Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Kinetics of Autonomous Catalytic Nanomotors in Confined and Crowded Environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to investigate the transport of autonomous nanomotors driven by chemical reactions in confined and crowded environments by integrating experiment and numerical simulations.
Intellectual Merits: The work is built on the PIs? recent success in design and fabrication of catalytic nanomotors with translational and rotational motion. By elucidating new issues unique to the transport of autonomous nanomotors in confined spaces and in presence of other particles and motors with different thermal, mechanical, and chemical interactions, the proposed research will break new ground for fundamental studies of particulate transport phenomena and enrich the theories of particulate transport. The proposed work will benefit from the synergistic collaboration between two PIs with complementary expertise in nanomotor fabrication/characterization and multi-physics simulations, and is supported by state-of-the-art computing and experimental facilities.
Broader Impacts: The proposed work addresses some of the most pressing issues in understanding the transport of nanomotors in practical applications, and the insights gained here will form the theoretical foundation for engineering smart nanomotor systems for targeted drug delivery and disease treatment, which can potentially transform these fields. The project will include strong and sustained education programs involving both undergraduate students with diverse ethnical backgrounds and regional K-12 students. Undergraduate research experience helps students, many of them minorities, develop a genuine interest in science and engineering through hands-on research activities in STEM disciplines. Outreach efforts will include providing high school students with immersive research experiences and showcasing research in university-level K-12 outreach programs. The interdisciplinary nature of this project, with a unique combination of experiments and simulations, will provide the students involved with a unique exposure to cutting-edge science and engineering.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: VIRGINIA POLYTECH INST AND STATE UN

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Micro/nanomotors, particles that are driven by the catalytic reactions on their surface or other external means, have shown promise in diverse applications including delivering small particles, cleaning up pollutant molecules, and repairing micro-cracks. With further development, they can potentially be used to perform challenging tasks such as delivering drugs to specific targets in the human body. Micro/nanomotors often must operate under confined and/or crowded conditions, e.g., a cluster of micromotors may have to navigate through a narrow capillary. Achieving the full potential of micro/nanomotors thus necessitates a fundamental understanding of their dynamics under these conditions.

In this project, several sets of studies were performed to study the dynamics of micro/nanomotors in confined and/or crowded environments using numerical simulations. In the first set of study, we investigated the transport of Janus catalytic micromotors (JCMs) through narrow capillaries and their dynamics in thin liquid films. Simulations revealed that the transport of JCMs through short pores with a diameter comparable to their diameter is slowed down by the pore walls, but the slowdown is far weaker than the slowdown of particulate transport driven by other mechanisms such as gravity. We identified that the modification of the mass transport of chemical species by the confinement is essential for explaining the observed slowdown. Crowding of JCMs affects the transport of the micromotors involved but the effect depends strongly on their relative positions. For JCMs confined in thin liquid films, a bubble can form only on sufficiently large JCMs because the formation of critical bubble embryo becomes increasingly more difficult as the JCM shrinks, and the latter is caused by the more effective mass diffusion as the JCM size reduces. When evaporation occurs on the surface of the thin liquid film in which JCMs are immersed, the slight temperature difference between the film surface and the solid wall can induce a flow near the bubbles inside the liquid film, and such a flow drives fast, collective movement of JCMs toward the bubble base. In the second set of study, which is triggered by an unexpected discovery in the experimental studies performed by our research collaborators, we investigated the movement of magnetic clusters driven by non-uniform AC magnetic fields. Unlike a permanent magnet pulling a magnetic particle, the magnetic clusters move away from the magnetic source with a periodic fluctuation in its trajectory that varies with a frequency twice of the AC magnetic field. We discovered that the movement of the cluster is a synergistic effect of the small magnetophoresis force acting on the cluster by the non-uniform field, the interactions between magnetic cluster, fluid flow, and the nearby walls, and the magnetic torque imposed on the magnetic cluster. The new particle manipulation method, which is extremely simple yet highly effective, has a great potential in applications such as cell biology and microfluidics.


Last Modified: 06/29/2017
Modified by: Rui Qiao
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Micro/nanomotors, particles that are driven by the catalytic reactions on their surface or other external means, have shown promise in diverse applications including delivering small particles, cleaning up pollutant molecules, and repairing micro-cracks. With further development, they can potentially be used to perform challenging tasks such as delivering drugs to specific targets in the human body. Micro/nanomotors often must operate under confined and/or crowded conditions, e.g., a cluster of micromotors may have to navigate through a narrow capillary. Achieving the full potential of micro/nanomotors thus necessitates a fundamental understanding of their dynamics under these conditions. In this project, several sets of studies were performed to study the dynamics of micro/nanomotors in confined and/or crowded environments using numerical simulations. In the first set of study, we investigated the transport of Janus catalytic micromotors (JCMs) through narrow capillaries and their dynamics in thin liquid films. Simulations revealed that the transport of JCMs through short pores with a diameter comparable to their diameter is slowed down by the pore walls, but the slowdown is far weaker than the slowdown of particulate transport driven by other mechanisms such as gravity. We identified that the modification of the mass transport of chemical species by the confinement is essential for explaining the observed slowdown. Crowding of JCMs affects the transport of the micromotors involved but the effect depends strongly on their relative positions. For JCMs confined in thin liquid films, a bubble can form only on sufficiently large JCMs because the formation of critical bubble embryo becomes increasingly more difficult as the JCM shrinks, and the latter is caused by the more effective mass diffusion as the JCM size reduces. When evaporation occurs on the surface of the thin liquid film in which JCMs are immersed, the slight temperature difference between the film surface and the solid wall can induce a flow near the bubbles inside the liquid film, and such a flow drives fast, collective movement of JCMs toward the bubble base. In the second set of study, which is triggered by an unexpected discovery in the experimental studies performed by our research collaborators, we investigated the movement of magnetic clusters driven by non-uniform AC magnetic fields. Unlike a permanent magnet pulling a magnetic particle, the magnetic clusters move away from the magnetic source with a periodic fluctuation in its trajectory that varies with a frequency twice of the AC magnetic field. The new particle manipulation method, which is extremely simple yet highly effective, has a great potential in applications such as cell biology and microfluidics.
